Nouns are words denoting people, places, animals, things or processes, e.g.: Evvan 'Evvan' (a name), Â’vvel 'Ivalo' (a place), nijdd 'girl', piânnai 'dog', sä’ltt 'salt', histoor 'history'.
Nouns are generally declined in cases, which are inflectional forms marking the function a noun has in a sentence. In Skolt Saami we distinguish between nine different cases:

ul.li: The nominative case is the base or presentational form: Põrtt lij mooččâd. 'The house is nice.'
The accusative case is the form marking the object: sie’zz 'aunt' (in English, the direct, meaning accusative, object always occurs after the finite verb: I like my aunt.)
The genitive indicates the possessor: Põõrt pirrõs lij mooččâd. 'The surrounding area of the house is nice.' (Note that English uses the so-called of-genitive in most cases.)
The illative is used to indicate motion to or into something: Mon puäđam siõm põõrtâst. 'I am coming from this little house.'
The locative provides the notions on/at/in a place or from a place: Son jäälast siõm põõrtâst. 'She lives in this small house.'
The comitative is the case providing the meaning "with": siõ’zzin. 'with aunt' (as in: I came with my aunt.)
The abessive is used to indicate the lack or absence of something, i.e. providing the meaning "without": sie’zztää 'without aunt' (as in: I had to go there without my aunt.)
The essive is the state case, which often gives the notion "as, like": sie’ssen 'as/like aunt' (as in: I am as tall as my aunt.)
The partitive case divides something into parts: sie’ssed 'a part of the aunt'

body.p: The essive and partitive cases occur only in the singular.
In Skolt Saami, there is variation in inflectional suffixes for nouns.

The inflectional stem and relevant affixes are determined by the inflectional class (I-IX) a noun belongs to, while the sub-group (A, B or C) stipulates which kind of sound change the stem vowel will undergo.
It is important that you also pay attention to diphthong simplification and stem gradation when inflecting Skolt Saami nouns.
